div.div: Piaget's Six Stages of the Sensorimotor Stage

switch.text: Piaget's Six Stages of the Sensorimotor Stage

div.div: During this period, the various reflexes that determine the infant’s interactions with the world are at the centre of its cognitive life.

switch.text: During this period, the various ref...

div.div: The sucking reflex causes the infant to suck at anything placed in its lips.

switch.text: The sucking reflex causes the infant to su...

div.div: First habits and primary circular reactions

div.div: At this age infants begin to coordinate what were separate actions into single, integrated activities.

switch.text: At this age infants begin to coordi...

div.div: An infant might combine grasping an object with sucking on it, or staring at something with touching it.

switch.text: An infant might combine grasping an object...

div.div: During this period, infants take major strides in shifting their cognitive horizons beyond themselves and begin to act on the outside world.

switch.text: During this period, infants take ma...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 252px; height: 1px; padding-top: 250px; margin-left: 558px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 96px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: A child who repeatedly picks up a rattle in her crib and shakes it in different ways to see how the sound changes is demonstrating her ability to modify her cognitive scheme about shaking rattles.

switch.text: A child who repeatedly picks up a rattle i...

div.div: In this stage, infants begin to use more calculated approaches to producing events, coordinating several schemes to generate a single act. They achieve object permanence during this stage.

switch.text: In this stage, infants begin to use...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 252px; height: 1px; padding-top: 345px; margin-left: 558px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 86px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: An infant will push one toy out of the way to reach another toy that is lying, partially exposed, under it.

switch.text: An infant will push one toy out of the way...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 68px; height: 1px; padding-top: 450px; margin-left: 1px;

div.div: At this age infants develop what Piaget regards as the deliberate variation of actions that bring desirable consequences. Rather than just repeat enjoyable activities, infants appear to carry out miniature experiments to observe the consequences.

switch.text: At this age infants develop what Pi...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 252px; height: 1px; padding-top: 450px; margin-left: 558px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 116px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: A child will drop a toy repeatedly, varying the position from which he drops it, carefully observing each time to see where it falls.

switch.text: A child will drop a toy repeatedly, varyin...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 68px; height: 1px; padding-top: 565px; margin-left: 1px;

div.div: The major achievement of Substage 6 is the capacity for mental representation or symbolic thought. Piaget argued that only at this stage can infants imagine where objects that they cannot see might be.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 252px; height: 1px; padding-top: 565px; margin-left: 558px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 106px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Children can even plot in their heads unseen
trajectories of objects, so that if a ball rolls
under a piece of furniture, they can figure out
where it is likely to emerge on the other side.

switch.text: Children can even plot in their heads unse...
